posts.cooked:
I am missing the possibility to create groups where only the creator can see the members and post to that group, for sending out information about events or something like that. That would be useful if you have a larger group of people to inform who do not know each other or at least are not very close to each other.

This could be a teacher informing his students, or a medical practice, basically any event where you know the main person/organisation but not the other participants.

I think this would be useful for a lot of people and it should not be too difficult to implement as it is just a small restriction to the existing group feature. And it could help to implement other features like the recently requested status updates (In that case a user would have a default group called “status” and his friends can join that group if they want to know the current status.)

I agree with @theBoatman that this would be a very useful feature. In Telegram, the feature is called “channels”. Additionally to the examples, @theBoatman gave, people use it a lot for inviting to their birthday parties, to keep friends updated while they travel, and so on.

Unfortunately, this feature and missing group admin support are still the main blockers for people to switch completely from Telegram to Signal.

What should happen if user replies? Only you should get a reply and others users in this InfoGroup should not get a reply, is it?

I suggested similar thing a while a go. I would like to send single message to multiple users like broadcasting. For example at new year’s day I send new year wishes to a lot of people they do not know each other. If I create a group then anyone that replies all of the people in group gets message. That is insane people that do not know each other would get a message. In this case I don’t want to create a group, just to be able to select multiple users to send one single message to them. This is similar to the InfoGroup/channel idea, just simpler, no group is needed to be created.

Like I see it, the difference between InfoGroup/channel is, InfoGroup/channel should be used if multiple messages are planed to be send in the future to the same group of users. Like in my case new year wish, probably next year I will send message to some other people - new coming in and old going out. My case is more volatile, so creating “pseudo” group is not reasonable.

theBoatman:

I think it is easier to implement

Telegram channels (and most whatsapp groups as I understand it) can be joined via “invite links” which are passed around. If I understand what theBoatman is suggesting, there is actually a very straightforward way to implement at least SOME of the desired functionality. What usually happens with a groupchat is this:

  • creator clicks New Group
  • creator clicks Add Member (usually multiple times)
  • creator sets groupchat title & avatar-pic
  • signalapp forwards a copy of the CC-list to all newly-added groupchat members
  • when a groupchat message is sent out, it is encrypted pairwise for every recipient, and the “to” field is specified as being the target-groupchat
  • any member can alter their local copy of the CC-list, either by Leave Group (themselves only) or using Add Member (inviting a new person)
  • all such updates are sync’d to all groupchat members so they can update their CC-lists locally as well

With “infoGroups” aka one-way signal-blasts, instead we have something slightly different:

  • creator clicks New InfoGroup (or OneWayGroup or BccGroup)
  • creator clicks Add Member (usually multiple times)
  • creator sets groupchat title & avatar-pic
  •  signalapp forwards a copy of the CC-list to all newly-added groupchat members  
  • when a groupchat message is sent out, it is encrypted pairwise for every recipient  , and the “to” field is specified as being the target-groupchat  
  •   any member can alter their local copy of the CC-list, either by Leave Group (themselves only) or using Add Member (inviting a new person)  
  •   all such updates are sync’d to all groupchat members so they can update their CC-lists locally as well  
  • creator can click the new Remove Member menu-option in their BCC-list

The steps above assume that the creator has a named InfoGroup-aka-BccGroup on their own device (and any linked devices thereto), but nobody else gets a copy. This requires a different menu-option be added for creation, and once created, inside the Edit Group submenu there needs to be an option for the group-creator-and-owner to Remove Member, as well as the usual Add Member / Rename Group / etc options that already exist. Other than those two relatively-simple additions, everything else is elimination of steps that classic signalapp groupchats do: distributing the CC-list to all groupchat members, letting groupchat members click Leave Group, letting groupchat members click Add Member, sync’ing all such changes to all recipients, letting groupchat members reply-to-the-group.

In this implementation-description, when the creator of an InfoGroup sends out a signal-blast, the recipients see it arrive “just like” a normal 1-on-1 message in the usual conversation. So in practice, they cannot tell that the sender was using an InfoGroup… on their end it appears as if the sender was just sending them a normal direct message. Similarly, if they reply, that reply will go directly to the sender, and appear on the sender’s end in the 1-on-1 chat with the person. For that matter, the sender will see their outgoing signal-blasts appear within the 1-on-1 conversations with each infogroup member. The only place where the “infogroup” is visible in a conversation-list, is on the sender/creator devices, and it ONLY shows the outgoing messages that were blasted out, never any replies to those messages.

In the long run, I think a better solution is to add groupchat-admins, who are able to control the content of the distributed-CC-lists on all devices… but I agree that this suggested InfoGroups feature is something that can be implemented immediately, and does not require any groupchat admin to make it happen. 98% of the code is written, in fact, so this is a plausible candidate for a small and targeted pull-request. But we need to make sure that the name is right (infogroup?), and that we are not forgetting any weird corner-cases.

It would also be ideal, if there was some thought put into whether this InfoGroup UI/UX would nicely dovetail with the eventual release of a proper groupchat-admin feature. We do not want to accidentally make it harder to implement groupchat-admins, in the process of adding a small-and-easy-to-implement InfoGroup upgrade.

I also think we should consider whether we want to support nested InfoGroups

  • Alice makes an infogroup called AB containing Bob and herself
  • Alice clicks Add Member to include Carl, and renames it to infogroup-abc
  • Alice makes an new infogroup called AD, containing David and herself
  • Alice clicks Add Member to include (nested) infogroup-abc, and renames the parent to infogroup-abcd

As well as whether we want to support classic-groupchats as potential ‘members’ of an InfoGroup:

  • Alice clicks add-member on infogroup-abcd and adds Frederic… when Alice sends out an infogroup-blast, one copy of the outgoing message will be sent (“from Alice”) insider her one-on-one chat with Frederic
  • Alice clicks add-member on infogroup-abcd and adds GroupchatForMondayTeam… when Alice sends out an infogroup-blast, one copy of the outgoing message will be sent (“from Alice”) inside the N-on-N groupchat with her monday-team people.

shellSignal:

channel

Channel is derivative of “television channel” as in saying “we need to change to channel five” or similar. Channel specifically indicates a kind of one-way-broadcast-transmission, with the inability to reply whatsoever. Generally, when you are watching channel five, and you see Walter Cronkite say something you disagree with, there is literally nothing you can do. You do not have his telephone-number. You do not have him watching a television where your commentary is being broadcast. The channel metaphor is strictly one-way.

The two concepts that we are attempting to wrestle with here, are not the same thing as an old-school television-channel, where Walter Cronkite can speak and you (and your neighbors as well) can all listen, but that is the end of it. To me, what we are talking about here would be termed a “signal-blast” rather than a “signal-channel” … Alice is blasting out a message to a bunch of people, but they CAN in fact reply to her (unlike to Cronkite). This is similar to the terminology used with SMS-blasts and also to a lesser degree with email-blasts. Classic traditional signalapp groupchats are “CcGroups” where every person knows the phone-number of every other person, and are similar to the way that MMS groups work.

The “infogroup” concept, to the extent I understand it, works like this:

  • Alice can send out an infogroup message to 99 people
  • Alice can see the phone numbers of all 99 people, plus also has separate 1-on-1 chat-conversation channels with them, if needed
  • all 99 can see they are talking to Alice, and see what her phone number is
  • the infogroup has a name, something like “Xyz-Info-from-Alice (one-way group)”
  • every recipient can see what the groupname is, and has a conversation-list item on their device with that infogroup’s details
  • none of the recipients can click ‘Edit Group’ and see who the other recipients are … the option is greyed out on their ends, with a tooltip which says “only the infogroup creator [Alice] can view and edit infogroup membership”
  • none of the recipients can reply to the whole group… when they try to do so, ONLY alice will see their messages… and presumably on Alice’s end, the messages appear in her copy of the “Xyz-Info-from-Alice (one-way group)” just as they will appear to Carl on his device when he replies… but only Alice & Carl will see what Carl said?
      The downside here is that Alice will likely reply directly to Carl, right in the infogroup-conversation, and thereby inadvertently shoot herself in the foot by blasting the reply-to-Carl out to all 99 people.
      So I think what actually needs to happen, is that when Carl tries to reply to the info-from-alice messages, what occurs is that he is redirected to his 1-on-1 conversation with Alice, but with the name of the infogroup in an automagically-generated quoted-reply? That way Alice knows what Carl is thinking about, and Alice can reply normally without any footgun incident.

Implementing THAT kind of thing is not really very easy. There are a lot of new things that need to be coded, tested, re-designed, rewritten, re-tested, and bulletproof’d. It is basically the sort of thing where, when Alice first clicks “Create InfoGroup” (or whatever it gets called) on her device, under the hood what happens is that 99 ‘normal’ signalapp groups are created … each of the subgroups contains Alice plus one other infogroup-member. So there is a subgroup where Alice+Bob can communicate, a subgroup where Alice+Carl can communicate, and so on. The subgroups appear on Bob’s device and on Carl’s device, but they are different from usual: Edit Group is greyed out, and when Bob or Carl try to reply to their subgroup, they get redirected over to their 1-on-1 conversation with Alice instead. As for Alice, on her device things are really weird: she cannot see any of the 99 subgroups, all she sees is one big “Xyz-Info-from-Alice” supergroup in her conversation-list, and this does have an Edit InfoGroup button available, and does let Alice send out messages (to all 99 recipients). However, as noted above, I expect that Alice will want to receive any replies she gets in the 1-on-1 chats she has with each of the 99 members, with a quoted-reply to indicate they are referring to Xyz-Info specifically. Is that all about right, and aligns with what you are proposing, @theBoatman?

Now, the “BccGroup” is quite different operationally, in a couple of ways:

  • Alice can send out a BccBlast message to 99 people
  • Alice can see the phone numbers of all 99 people, plus also has separate 1-on-1 chat-conversation channels with them, if needed
  • all 99 can see they are talking to Alice, and see what her phone number is
  • the BccBlast has a name, something like “Alice’s List Of Xyz Team (one-way blast)”
  •  every recipient can see what the groupname is, and has a conversation-list item on their device with that infogroup’s details   only Alice can see the groupname of the BccBlast, and only Alice has a conversation-list item on her devices called BccBlast
  • none of the recipients can click ‘Edit Group’ and see who the other recipients are …   the option is greyed out on their ends, with a tooltip which says “only the infogroup creator [Alice] can view and edit infogroup membership”   … from their perspective there IS no ‘group’ at all
  • none of the recipients can reply to the whole group… because there is no ‘group’ from their perspective, only from Alice’s perspective, which means when Carl tries to reply to the BccBlast-from-Alice messages, he does it as usual from his 1-on-1 conversation with Alice. Now, when Alice sends out a BccBlast, a copy of the blast-message appears in her special “Alice’s List of Xyz Team” conversation-item conversation history, but because each individual received the message into their normal 1-on-1 chat with Alice, both the recipients and Alice can see a copy of the bccBlast-message within that 1-on-1 chat. Thus, Alice knows what Carl it thinking about when he replies, because the bccBlast message is right there in the conversation-history with Carl.

This is a different thing that the infogroup concept, and is basically a group that is “only in Alice’s mind” which the other participants might not be aware of. They do not have a way to know they are getting some kind of BccBlast… nor what the name of the BccBlast member-list might be… unless Alice wants them to know. The point of the BccBlast is to let Alice blast out a form-letter. “Dear everybody, family reunion at 123 main st, show up any time after 3pm, dinner at 6ish, rsvp to Alice please.” It is easier for Alice to organize that kind of thing, and send out reminders and change-notices and whatnot (“please stop parking on the petunias”) if she creates a BccBlast with all the participants listed. But it is primarily just a list of names, used for convenience to avoid pasting the same boilerplate 99 times. Alice probably has a bunch of sublists, besides her 99-member 2018-family-reunion superlist: she has a list of Baggins-side, a list of Boffins-side, a list of Bracegirdle-side, and so on… helps if she can create nested BccBlasts… but complicates the UI/UX.

The infogroup is something else, it is meant for more structured kinds of things. Alice is the organizer of a baseball-team-tournament, and there are sixteen teams 0 thru F which each have a coach, a pitcher, outfielders, and so on. Alice creates sixteen infogroups named for each of the teams, something like “Team#0x0 aardvarks” and “Team#0x1 bobcats” all the way through “Team#0xF porcupines”. Then, to send out tournament-wide-info, Alice also creates a nested infogroup which contains all of the sixteen teams, plus the umpires (whom do not participate in team-practices but do need to be in the loop about the tournament). Every time a message goes out to the porcupines, they know it is about the porcupines. Every time a tournament-wide info-blast goes out, all the teams know it is info-for-everybody. The coach of the porcupines will probably create a normal groupchat for her team, so they can discuss strategy in the usual N-to-N fashion. Or maybe the players do not wish to share phone numbers with each other, in which case the coach can create a porcupine-specific bccBlast or a porcupine-specific infogroup… is there a way for the porcupine coach to send a message to Alice’s porcupine infogroup, or only for Alice to do that?

5_c_d:

Is that all about right, and aligns with what you are proposing, @theBoatman?

That sounds much more complicated than what I have in mind. I would not let anybody respond directly inside the group to the creator because that makes things complicated as you described. If Alice creates the group then it is her group and everyone else just reads it. Then it is really the same code as normal groups, except that when Alice adds Bob he doesn’t get the list of the other group members and is not allowed to write there. He sees that he is in that group. He sees the title. He gets the messages. No reply, no invitation, no title editing.

I would really stay as close as possible to the existing code. Then it can get implemented fast, and everything else can wait till we have a good solution for group admins.

My initial intention was to get good functionality for groups with as little effort as possible.

I would like what you are talking about, but I suspect it will not get accepted as a pull request into the main repo. UX is too ‘unfriendly’ to Bob. Are you okay with forking into a test-repo, or something like that? As long as you are careful to keep your copyright ducks and your derivative-work swans all in a proper row, you can eventually hope to upmerge. But if you are wanting to write this up as a proper pull-request for the main repo, I suggest we will need to get a sense of whether what you are proposing has a good/poor/almostNone chance of actually getting merged. There are a lot of unmerged ideas out there; not trying to discourage you, I like your thinking

Hold on, I see someone edited this topic to also be about broadcasts. But This was originally a topic about Channels (aka infoGroups). These are not the same thing!

A broadcast list is something you can make to send one message to multiple people in the already existing one-on-one chat without inviting them first to some separate channel.

I propose we keep these discussions separate. This topic was a feature request for channels (aka info-groups). Here is a topic about Broadcast lists (similar to WhatsApp) - #3 by Meteor0id

Yes, I did.
The term broadcast inherently implies a one-way direction to multiple recipients. I did add it in case someone else tries to search for a similar topic. In my eyes I would rather rename the other topic to something like “send message to multiple recipients without creating a group”.
